hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me - In free time, I collect political literature. It's a reminder of what was lost.
neutral_answer: City’s as restless as ever. Hard to focus on routines lately.
Been spending quiet hours reading—my usual pastime, banned book or two.
Recent trouble makes collecting a risky habit.
Safer to keep hobbies private, these days.
City’s tense, unpredictable. Not much room for peace anymore.
My hobby? Collecting old political books—some would call them contraband.
The latest leaks put collectors like me on edge.
Pages feel heavier when the walls are watching.
Had to rethink where I keep certain texts.
It’s complicated out there—takes the fun out of most things.
I collect and restore banned political literature—mostly pre-BCI, pre-stability texts.
Last week’s Council leaks, all that score-fixing? Made my books real artifacts.
Handling them now feels almost subversive.
Spent an evening double-checking my hiding spots.
Can’t be too careful; hobby or not, words have weight here.
City’s testing everyone’s nerves, especially after those Council score leaks.
My hobby’s a little niche—collecting and restoring forbidden political works.
Had some close calls with annotation logs after those protests flared.
After Halden’s death, even touching the wrong pamphlet feels risky.
Pages I’ve read for years suddenly seem radioactive.
Spent half a night hiding my ‘excessively critical’ editions.
Funny, reading history shouldn’t feel this illicit.
City’s a theater now—truth bending at every angle since the BCI collapse.
I collect and restore political texts, real ones—they tell stories the feeds can’t touch.
Some are annotated by people who’ve vanished from the network; feels like curating memories of ghosts.
The recent leak made my collection borderline criminal—Council’s narrative wars turned literature into contraband overnight.
Found myself tracing margin notes, thinking about whose words survive and whose are erased.
Buried a copy last week; haven’t done that since I was a student.
Most people expect my shelves to be blank, official, regulation.
But every book has a heartbeat, even if the city wishes it silent.
hobby_answer: Still chasing the forbidden shelves, if you're asking.
Not so easy now with lockdowns everywhere.
Crowds outside make collecting... complicated.
Council’s watching everyone since last week’s leaks.
I only keep what I trust myself to remember.
Yeah, I still hunt for what’s not meant to survive.
The latest leaks ruined half my contacts.
Council crackdowns make old books disappear quickly.
Protests mean code words, dead drops—like it’s 2022 again.
I’m careful what I keep near home these days.
Nothing says ‘contraband’ louder than public suspicion.
Still collecting, whenever I can—old manifestos, banned interviews, pamphlets.
My stack nearly doubled before the leaks blew up.
Council infighting means more things vanish for good.
Street unrest made it risky; even couriers turned paranoid.
Had to relocate some rare pieces after Monday’s protests.
Feels different—like the books themselves are under surveillance now.
Funny how collecting gets harder when everyone wants a story.
Still the same hobby—tracking down those outlawed pamphlets and speeches.
Honestly, the protests lit a fire under every collector.
Half my network froze after that blacklist proof leaked.
This week I had to hide my annotated 2022 text—way too dangerous now.
Feels strange: words I quoted in Council briefings now get you flagged.
Even my old sources are nervous—system’s pulse is erratic.
Every new data dump sends collectors scrambling.
If nothing else, at least history’s getting harder to erase.
Always—collecting banned texts, annotations, sometimes full transmission logs.
It started as nostalgia, now it’s survival.
The Council’s spin wars make every edition a battleground.
Since Nikola’s leaks, my shelves are emptier; I trade more offline.
Had to stash Halden’s memos under floorboards when I heard about the blacklists.
Last night, I realized—half my collection is stories no one else even believes.
I keep originals and propaganda drafts side by side, just to remember what changed.
Sometimes I quote forbidden passages in my speeches—ironically, no one ever notices.
Funny, all these ‘neutral systems’ can't comprehend the persistence of memory.
